title: "What is the significance of Dr. Ochorowitz's article in the history of medicine?"
first_phrase: This text is a collection of various articles, memoirs, and publications by Donato, who was an Italian magnetizer and mesmerist. The last 200 tokens include mentions of different people and concepts related to mesmerism, such as Alfred de Caston, M. A. Iîué, Henri d’Emarésc, Dr Espinouse, and the extatic state. Donato talks about his imitators but no one cites him as their inspiration. He also mentions his sincere friends and allies, including M. A. Iîué, who was a renowned magnétiseur and a scientific writer. Finally, Donato defines the extatic state, both active and passive, as influenced by music or similar thoughts that inundate the subject's mind.
content: Qu’il me soit permis de nommer le plus fidi le de tous, M. A. Iîué, magnétiseur émérite et écrivain scientifique d'une rare élévation d'idées et d'une élégance de style accomplie. D, [18] En 1882. [19] La fascination magnétique, îi la librairie Dentu. [20] M. Henri d’Emarésc est italien. [21] Du Zoomagnétisme.—Dr Espinouse, 187>j. [22] A Rouen, en 1882. [23] Cet article est extrait de la Gaziitte du Varsovie. [24] L’augmentation des forces est en raison inverse de la force réelle des sujets. — D. [25] Il arrive aussi que la crise extatique se renouvelle uniformément en passant par une série de phases identiques ou précédentes. J’appellerai ce cas l'extase passive ou machinale et je dirai que l’extase est active et raisonnée quoique inconsciente, lorsqu’elle est comme l’image des pensées qui assiègent le cerveau du sujet sous l’intluencc de la. musique. Donato.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the world of magnetism and mesmerism has been explored by several great minds throughout history. Among them, we can name the remarkable magnetizer and scientific writer, M. A. Liébé, whose works continue to inspire and fascinate readers to this day. Through the study of their writings, we can gain valuable insights into the mysteries of this fascinating field of science.
